meanings.definition: The act of treating some people unfairly because of prejudice.
examples: The civil rights movement fought to bring an end to discrimination in this country.

images.alt: Photo of bench and sign: "For Colored Patrons Only"
images.description: This photo shows a wooden bench. At the top of the back of the bench is a sign which reads, 'For Colored Patrons Only.'
images.caption: During segregation, Black Americans were discriminated against were forced to use seating that was less comfortable than white people.

examples: The Civil Rights Movement helped guarantee that all American citizens would be treated equally.

images.alt: Photo of two people shaking hands.
images.caption: Shaking hands is one way to be civil to another person.

examples: There was a lot of resistance to the plan when it was first suggested.

meanings.definition: To celebrate (a holiday) or honor (a person or event).
examples: They observed a moment of silence to remember their loved ones.

images.alt: Photo of people gathered at a ceremony.
images.description: People are gathered, standing, in a group, facing four people dressed in military uniforms. Two of the military people are holding flags, one U.S. flag and the other a Navy flag. A military band is in the background.
images.caption: People gathered to observe and remember Veterans Day.

meanings.definition: To enroll, as in a course of study or as a voter.
examples: Have you registered to vote yet?

images.alt: Photo of two people standing at a table.
images.description: Two people stand at a table, helping people to register to vote. A sign behind them reads, 'Are you registered to vote at your current address?'
images.caption: Students on a college campus can help others to register to vote.

meanings.definition: To bring in something new to an environment.
examples: She introduced music to me when I was very young.

images.alt: Photo of Barack Obama speaking to an audience.
images.description: A man stands on a stage behind a podium, with American flags in the background. His is talking, and his arms are extended out to his sides. Part of a large crowd is in front of him, waving American flags and signs that say, "change"
images.caption: Barack Obama's candidacy began a new era for American politics.

source.title: Presidential candidate Barack Obama speaks to the audience at the Democratic National Convention, Denver, Colorado, August 25-28, 2008
source.author: Photographs in the Carol M. Highsmith Archive, Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division.

examples: She was used to the constant hum of the traffic outside her window.
My mom was very supportive when I needed help studying for my test.

images.alt: Photo of a runner and a person extending their hand out in support.
images.description: A person extends a hand out in support of a runner.
images.caption: Supporting someone's efforts can help them keep going to the finish.

meanings.definition: Having the distinctive qualities of a particular type of person or thing.
examples: A typical baby walks at about one year old.
His bad test grade did not discourage him, because he knew he could do better next time.

images.alt: Photo of a person sitting outside on steps, head down  and shoes off.
images.description: A person sitting outside on stone steps. His head is down, resting on his arms which are over his knees. The person's shoes are on the ground beside the person.
images.caption: Sometimes, like here, you can see how discouraged someone is.

meanings.definition: To bring in something new to an environment.
examples: She proposed that I learn music when I was very young.

images.alt: Photo of Barack Obama speaking to an audience.
images.description: A man stands on a stage behind a podium, with American flags in the background. His is talking, and his arms are extended out to his sides. Part of a large crowd is in front of him, waving American flags and signs that say, "change"
images.caption: Barack Obama's candidacy began a new era for American politics.

source.title: Presidential candidate Barack Obama speaks to the audience at the Democratic National Convention, Denver, Colorado, August 25-28, 2008
source.author: Photographs in the Carol M. Highsmith Archive, Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division.

examples: She was used to the unrelenting hum of the traffic outside her window.
My mom was very sympathetic when I needed help studying for my test.

images.alt: Photo of a runner and a person extending their hand out in support.
images.description: A person extends a hand out in support of a runner.
images.caption: Supporting someone's efforts can help them keep going to the finish.

examples: A conventional baby walks at about one year old.
His bad test grade did not dishearten him because he knew he could do better next time.

images.alt: Photo of a person sitting outside on steps, head down  and shoes off.
images.description: A person sitting outside on stone steps. His head is down, resting on his arms which are over his knees. The person's shoes are on the ground beside the person.
images.caption: Sometimes, like here, you can see how disheartened someone is.
